title: The worst Kentucky Derby ever | Meteorology | messenger-inquirer.com
text:
They say everybody should go to the Kentucky Derby at least once in their lives.
I did.
They say everybody should go to the Kentucky Derby at least once in their lives.
I did.
And that was more than enough for me.
It was one of the most miserable days horses and race fans have ever had to endure at Churchill Downs.
It was May 6, 1989.
The weatherman called for rain in the morning with clearing skies and temperatures in the upper 50s to low 60s by post time.
That fellow would have been lynched if the crowd had found him at post time.
My wife told me to wear a heavier jacket.
But no, I believed the weatherman.
I just stuck a light rain jacket in the car — just in case.
The Kentucky Lottery was new that year, and the winner of the $1 million grand prize would be determined by the winner of the Derby.
I was there to cover the winner of the lottery, not the Derby.
In case you’re wondering, Sunday Silence won the race.
And Danny Hurley of Chavies won the million.
But that’s beside the point.
The real story was the weather.
It was 43 degrees at post time.
FORTY THREE DEGREES.
That’s 51 degrees colder than the record high — 94 degrees in 1959.
The crowd had already endured a day of wind, rain, hail and sleet.
And some even claimed to have seen a few snow flakes.
But it could have been just thick sleet.
People who had brought blankets to sit on in the infield wound up wearing them.
Coats covered spring frocks that women had spent considerable time and money on.
Wide-brimmed hats were worn with ear muffs as an accessory.
And hot chocolate was more in demand than mint juleps.
Of course, you could find the occasional attention-seeker all decked out in a bikini, claiming that she wasn’t the least bit cold.
But unless she was wearing blue lipstick, she was lying through her teeth.
It was a miserable day.
Both the track and the infield were listed as muddy.
And they were.
And unless you had a seat in the grandstands or along the rail somewhere, you could spend the whole day without seeing a horse.
Hundreds of people were huddled around TV sets near the betting windows, watching the race.
I can watch TV at home.
When I finally got back in the car — and got the heater cranked up — I decided that somebody up there didn’t want me at the Derby.
I was familiar with Jonah and the whale.
So, I’ve been doing the crowd a favor every year and staying home.
And you know what?
There hasn’t been a Derby day quite like that since.
Keith Lawrence; klawrence@messenger-inquirer.com
